body.p:
If I did not write you since long, it was only for the incerti
tude I had of you receiving my different previous? letters and books.
Now finding your note in your valuable paper and receiving
that paper regularly by favor of my friend Mr. de Sola I ?
of the occasion in writing ? to accuse you the
reception and to pray you to writing me that interesting
letter? and other productions of american jewish literature
you could forward to me. I have read the Spirit of Judaism
by Miss Aguilar and your notes with delight; you will have
received, I hope, the two annuals, 1855 and 56 now, and you
will have found the articles on that high-minded, angellike
writer, a ? as she was, has done more than any
celebrate authors for the sake of Judaism. The most of her
not-jewish publications are translated in Dutch and they
have been justly admired. I hope to give a translation
of her Jewish works, and the Sabbat-? are nearly
prepared for the press.

As for other jewish interests you will find
hereafter some lines and I propose myself to write you
soon more; now only having little time at my disposition
the letter to Mr. Arona? ought to be expediated immediately!

If saying him and his family will be so kind to
give them our hearty compliments and, if possible, write me soon,
tidings from your hand having an echo in my soul. I did demand
you already, I believe, some particulars on the deceased Mr.
da Silva Solis and his family, they being of my relations,
Believe me, Sir, without great protestations,

A point of great interest for the sake of
religious and political tolerations is nearly to be gained
in the states general: we will allude to the questions of
the elementar instruction. The government, answering to the
prescriptions of the Constitution and to the principles of
humanity and good policy highly in credit in the Netherlands
has proposed a law on the said instruction in a large spirit;
it had adopted the system of so called mixted schools

for the public instruction, leaving all liberty to the
communities or particulars to erect special religious institutions.
There has been a party of ultra protestants who decries that
system as unchristian and would have adopted the principle
of positive christianity even in the lower public schools, or
at least mentioned christian principles in the law. Another
protestant party, more liberal, has mentioned the ? of
government, as in ? with the true interests of the
country and religion herself; the lower public schools not being
the just places of carrying controverse or propaganda dogmata;
the mind of the children of all communions being only induced?
to find here recommendations to the more general truths of
all religious confessions, leaving it to parents and ministers
of every confession in particular to give religious instruction as they
believe properly. General truths also, general prayers, elevating
the mind of the little people to virtue and morality, without
dispute or controversies: that is the bases whereupon the
law now in discussion is to be put. The great majority
of the second Chamber of States General has declared
herself satisfied with that basis; so it will be probably
adopted in the course of some months.

The new organisation of the Israelite administra
tion is still to be looked for: the first outlines of that
administration date from 1848; there have been enough ?
?, projects and reports; but they have till yet.
We hope however the plan will not be put totaly in oblivion.

The portuguese Jews at Curacao have had the good idea
to call a chief rabbi from Amsterdam; M. Chumaceiro, who
has been installated already in that colony and aims, as it
appears, to ameliorate the religious instruction. Mr. Chu
manceiro, in leaving his community where he has been
preacher since many years, has taken adieu in a
very touching stile; we hope he will do a great
deal of good in the western countries.
